description: Controller-to-Processor agreements compliant with GDPR, UK GDPR, and CCPA/CPRA for handling personal data

clauses.title: Data Retention Period
clauses.plainDescription: How long can the processor retain personal data after the services end? When must data be deleted or returned?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR requires data minimization - personal data should not be kept longer than necessary. However, legal retention requirements may necessitate longer periods. The balance is between the controller's data protection obligations and practical business needs.

options.label: 30 Days
options.plainDescription: Processor must delete or return all personal data within 30 days of service termination.
options.legalText: Upon termination of the Principal Agreement, the Processor shall delete or return all Personal Data within thirty (30) days and certify such deletion in writing.

options.label: 60 Days
options.plainDescription: Processor has 60 days to delete or return all personal data after services end.
consPartyB: Still need to track and execute
options.legalText: Upon termination of the Principal Agreement, the Processor shall delete or return all Personal Data within sixty (60) days and certify such deletion in writing.

options.label: 90 Days
options.plainDescription: Processor has 90 days to delete or return all personal data, providing more time for complex data cleanup.
options.legalText: Upon termination of the Principal Agreement, the Processor shall delete or return all Personal Data within ninety (90) days and certify such deletion in writing.

clauses.title: Sub-Processor Approval
clauses.plainDescription: How must the processor obtain approval before engaging other companies (sub-processors) to help process personal data?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR Article 28 requires processors to obtain controller authorization before engaging sub-processors. The question is whether this is a general authorization with objection rights, or specific per-sub-processor approval.

options.label: Specific Prior Approval
options.plainDescription: Processor must obtain explicit written approval before engaging any new sub-processor. No general authorization.
options.legalText: The Processor shall not engage any Sub-processor without the Controller's prior specific written authorization. Any request to add a Sub-processor must be submitted in writing and approved by the Controller before engagement.

options.label: General Authorization (30-Day Notice)
options.plainDescription: General authorization to use sub-processors, but processor must give 30 days notice of changes. Controller can object on data protection grounds.
options.legalText: The Controller provides general authorization for the Processor to engage Sub-processors. The Processor shall notify the Controller of any intended changes at least thirty (30) days before the change. If the Controller objects on reasonable data protection grounds, the parties shall discuss in good faith.

options.label: General Authorization (14-Day Notice)
options.plainDescription: General authorization with only 14 days notice before adding new sub-processors. Controller can still object.
options.legalText: The Controller provides general authorization for the Processor to engage Sub-processors. The Processor shall notify the Controller of any intended changes at least fourteen (14) days before the change. The Controller may object on reasonable data protection grounds.

clauses.title: Data Breach Notification Timing
clauses.plainDescription: How quickly must the processor notify the controller of a personal data breach?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR requires processors to notify controllers 'without undue delay' after becoming aware of a breach, with controllers having 72 hours to notify regulators. CCPA/CPRA requires notification 'in the most expedient time possible.'

options.label: 24 Hours
options.plainDescription: Processor must notify controller within 24 hours of discovering a data breach.
prosPartyA: More time to assess and notify regulators
options.legalText: In the event of a Personal Data Breach, the Processor shall notify the Controller without undue delay, and in any event within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the breach.

CALIFORNIA.note: Exceeds CCPA 'expedient time' requirement - strong protection

SPAIN.note: Provides buffer for GDPR 72-hour regulatory deadline

options.label: 48 Hours
options.plainDescription: Processor must notify controller within 48 hours of discovering a data breach.
options.legalText: In the event of a Personal Data Breach, the Processor shall notify the Controller without undue delay, and in any event within forty-eight (48) hours of becoming aware of the breach.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Leaves 24-hour buffer for UK GDPR deadline

options.label: 72 Hours
options.plainDescription: Processor must notify controller within 72 hours of discovering a breach, aligned with GDPR regulatory timeline.
prosPartyA: Processor has time for initial investigation
options.legalText: In the event of a Personal Data Breach, the Processor shall notify the Controller without undue delay, and in any event within seventy-two (72) hours of becoming aware of the breach.

CALIFORNIA.note: Aligns with CCPA 'expedient' standard for most cases

ENGLAND_WALES.warning: Leaves no buffer before UK GDPR 72-hour regulatory deadline - controller must act immediately

SPAIN.warning: Leaves no buffer before GDPR 72-hour regulatory deadline - controller must act immediately

clauses.title: Audit Rights
clauses.plainDescription: What rights does the controller have to audit or inspect the processor's data protection practices?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR Article 28 requires processors to allow and contribute to audits by the controller. The scope and frequency of audits, and who bears the cost, are negotiable points.

options.label: Full On-Site Audit Rights
options.plainDescription: Controller may conduct on-site audits with reasonable notice, including inspecting facilities, systems, and records.
options.legalText: The Processor shall allow for and contribute to audits, including on-site inspections, conducted by the Controller or an auditor mandated by the Controller, subject to reasonable advance notice of at least thirty (30) days.

options.label: Third-Party Audit Reports
options.plainDescription: Processor provides SOC 2 or ISO 27001 audit reports. On-site audits only if reports are insufficient.
consPartyA: Reports may not cover specific concerns
options.legalText: The Processor shall make available SOC 2 Type II or ISO 27001 audit reports upon request. The Controller may conduct on-site audits only if third-party reports do not adequately address specific data protection concerns, with at least thirty (30) days' notice.

options.label: Certification Reports Only
options.plainDescription: Processor provides third-party audit reports and certifications. No on-site audit rights.
options.legalText: The Processor shall maintain SOC 2 Type II or equivalent certification and provide copies of audit reports to the Controller upon request. On-site audits are not permitted except as required by regulatory authorities.

clauses.title: International Data Transfers
clauses.plainDescription: How will personal data transfers outside the EEA/UK be handled and protected?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR restricts transfers outside the EEA unless adequate safeguards exist. Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) are the most common mechanism. CCPA does not have equivalent transfer restrictions but requires reasonable security.

options.label: EEA/UK Only (No Transfers)
options.plainDescription: Personal data will only be stored and processed within the EEA or UK. No international transfers permitted.
options.legalText: The Processor shall not transfer Personal Data outside the European Economic Area or United Kingdom. All processing shall occur within the EEA or UK.

CALIFORNIA.warning: This option is designed for EU/UK GDPR compliance. For California deals, select 'Flexible' or 'US Only' options which better align with CCPA requirements.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Strictest data residency - may limit processor choices but eliminates transfer risk

SPAIN.note: Strictest data residency - ensures full GDPR compliance with no transfer complexity

options.label: SCCs Required for Transfers
options.plainDescription: Transfers outside EEA/UK permitted only with Standard Contractual Clauses and supplementary measures where required.
options.legalText: Transfers outside the EEA or UK are permitted only where covered by Standard Contractual Clauses (EU Commission Decision 2021/914) and the UK International Data Transfer Addendum, with supplementary measures implemented where required.

CALIFORNIA.note: SCCs are not legally required under CCPA, but provide strong protection for international transfers

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Industry standard for UK GDPR compliance with international processors

SPAIN.note: Industry standard for GDPR compliance with international processors

options.label: Flexible (Adequacy or SCCs)
options.plainDescription: Transfers permitted to countries with adequacy decisions or under SCCs, giving processor maximum flexibility.
consPartyB: SCCs still needed for some transfers
options.legalText: Transfers outside the EEA or UK are permitted where: (a) the destination country has an adequacy decision; or (b) Standard Contractual Clauses are in place with supplementary measures where required.

CALIFORNIA.note: Recommended for California - provides reasonable safeguards without GDPR-specific mechanisms that may not be required

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Balanced approach for UK GDPR compliance

clauses.title: Liability Cap for Data Breaches
clauses.plainDescription: What is the maximum liability the processor faces for data protection breaches or violations?
clauses.legalContext: Data protection violations can result in significant fines (up to 4% of global turnover under GDPR). The allocation of liability between controller and processor is a key commercial negotiation point.

options.label: Unlimited Liability
options.plainDescription: No cap on processor liability for data protection violations or breaches.
consPartyA: Processor may refuse or charge more
options.legalText: The Processor's liability for breaches of this DPA or Data Protection Laws is not subject to any limitation or cap.

options.label: 2x Annual Fees
options.plainDescription: Processor liability capped at twice the annual fees paid under the agreement.
consPartyA: May not cover major breach costs
options.legalText: The Processor's aggregate liability for breaches of this DPA shall not exceed two times (2x) the fees paid or payable by the Controller in the twelve (12) months preceding the claim.

options.label: 1x Annual Fees
options.plainDescription: Processor liability capped at the annual fees paid under the agreement.
options.legalText: The Processor's aggregate liability for breaches of this DPA shall not exceed the fees paid or payable by the Controller in the twelve (12) months preceding the claim.

clauses.title: Data Subject Request Assistance
clauses.plainDescription: How will the processor help the controller respond to data subject requests (access, deletion, portability, etc.)?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR gives individuals rights over their personal data. Controllers must respond to requests, and processors must assist. The level of assistance and any associated costs are negotiable.

options.label: Full Assistance (Included)
options.plainDescription: Processor provides full assistance with all data subject requests at no additional cost.
consPartyA: Processor may build cost into base price
options.legalText: The Processor shall assist the Controller in responding to Data Subject requests at no additional cost, including providing relevant data and implementing technical measures to fulfill access, rectification, erasure, and portability requests.

options.label: Standard Assistance (Reasonable Efforts)
options.plainDescription: Processor provides reasonable assistance with data subject requests. High-volume or complex requests may incur fees.
options.legalText: The Processor shall provide reasonable assistance to the Controller in responding to Data Subject requests. The Processor may charge reasonable fees for assistance beyond normal operational support, with prior notice to the Controller.

options.label: Self-Service Tools Provided
options.plainDescription: Processor provides self-service tools for controller to handle data subject requests. Additional assistance available at extra cost.
consPartyA: May need to do more work
options.legalText: The Processor shall provide self-service tools enabling the Controller to respond to Data Subject requests. Additional manual assistance is available at Processor's then-current professional services rates.

clauses.title: Security Measures Standard
clauses.plainDescription: What security certifications or standards must the processor maintain?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR requires 'appropriate technical and organizational measures.' Specific certifications like SOC 2 or ISO 27001 provide independent verification of security practices.

options.label: ISO 27001 Required
options.plainDescription: Processor must maintain ISO 27001 certification throughout the agreement term.
options.legalText: The Processor shall maintain ISO 27001 certification covering the services provided under the Principal Agreement throughout the term of this DPA.

options.label: SOC 2 Type II Required
options.plainDescription: Processor must maintain SOC 2 Type II attestation, demonstrating operational effectiveness over time.
options.legalText: The Processor shall maintain SOC 2 Type II attestation covering Security, Availability, and Confidentiality trust service criteria throughout the term of this DPA.

options.label: Appropriate Measures (No Specific Certification)
options.plainDescription: Processor must implement appropriate security measures but no specific certification is required.
options.legalText: The Processor shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect Personal Data, taking into account the state of the art, costs, and nature of processing. Measures shall be documented in Annex 2.

clauses.title: DPIA Assistance
clauses.plainDescription: How will the processor assist with Data Protection Impact Assessments required by the controller?
clauses.legalContext: GDPR requires DPIAs for high-risk processing. Processors must assist controllers with DPIAs, but the scope and cost of assistance is negotiable.

options.label: Full DPIA Assistance (Included)
options.plainDescription: Processor provides comprehensive DPIA assistance including documentation and risk analysis at no additional cost.
options.legalText: The Processor shall provide comprehensive assistance with Data Protection Impact Assessments at no additional cost, including providing documentation on processing activities, security measures, and risk assessments.

options.label: Standard Information Provision
options.plainDescription: Processor provides necessary information for DPIAs. Extensive consultations may incur additional fees.
consPartyA: May face fees for complex DPIAs
options.legalText: The Processor shall provide information necessary for the Controller to conduct Data Protection Impact Assessments. Additional consulting support beyond standard documentation is available at Processor's professional services rates.

options.label: Documentation Only
options.plainDescription: Processor provides standard documentation. Controller responsible for conducting DPIA with this information.
options.legalText: The Processor shall make available documentation describing the processing activities, security measures, and Sub-processors to enable the Controller to conduct Data Protection Impact Assessments.

clauses.title: Processing Instructions
clauses.plainDescription: How strictly must the processor follow controller instructions, and what happens if instructions seem unlawful?
clauses.legalContext: Processors must only process data on documented controller instructions. However, processors also have compliance obligations and should flag potentially unlawful instructions.

options.label: Strict Compliance Required
options.plainDescription: Processor must strictly follow all documented controller instructions. Must inform controller immediately if any instruction appears unlawful.
options.legalText: The Processor shall process Personal Data only on documented instructions from the Controller. The Processor shall immediately inform the Controller if any instruction, in the Processor's opinion, infringes Data Protection Laws.

options.label: Standard Compliance
options.plainDescription: Processor follows controller instructions and service agreement. Must promptly notify controller of any apparent legal issues.
options.legalText: The Processor shall process Personal Data in accordance with documented instructions from the Controller and the terms of the Principal Agreement. The Processor shall promptly inform the Controller if any instruction appears to infringe Data Protection Laws.

options.label: Flexible (Within Service Scope)
options.plainDescription: Processing governed primarily by service agreement terms. Controller can provide additional specific instructions as needed.
consPartyB: Must ensure service terms are comprehensive
options.legalText: The Processor shall process Personal Data in accordance with the Principal Agreement, which constitutes the Controller's documented instructions. The Controller may provide additional written instructions as necessary, which the Processor shall follow unless they appear to infringe Data Protection Laws.

clauses.title: Dispute Resolution
clauses.plainDescription: How and where will disputes about this agreement be resolved? You can choose courts in the governing law jurisdiction, courts elsewhere, or private arbitration.
clauses.legalContext: For DPA disputes, the choice of forum can impact how data protection issues are interpreted. Courts in GDPR jurisdictions may have more experience with data protection matters.

options.label: Default Courts (Per Governing Law)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in courts of the governing law jurisdiction: San Francisco (California), London (England & Wales), or Madrid (Spain).
consPartyA: May be inconvenient for one party
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the state and federal courts located in the jurisdiction of the governing law. Each Party irrevocably submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of such courts.

options.label: Delaware Courts (Neutral - US)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in Delaware courts, known for sophisticated commercial law and business-friendly judiciary.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware (or, if such court lacks jurisdiction, the state and federal courts located in Delaware).

options.label: JAMS Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Private arbitration under JAMS rules - popular with technology companies handling data processing.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by binding arbitration administered by JAMS under its Comprehensive Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: ICC Arbitration
options.plainDescription: International arbitration under ICC rules - ideal for cross-border data processing arrangements.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator, with the seat in the capital of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: LCIA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under LCIA rules - preferred for UK/EU data processing disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the LCIA Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by a sole arbitrator appointed by the LCIA Court. The seat of arbitration will be London, United Kingdom.
